awd_titl_txt: Dynamics of macro-vortices in horizontal axis turbine wind farms
awd_abstract_narration:
Fluid dynamics and turbulent flow phenomena are known to play dominant roles in the performance, efficiency and environmental impact of wind farms. There is growing interest in using fluid dynamics knowledge to improve wind energy harvesting and thereby achieve societal benefits such as reduced greenhouse gas emissions and a renewable energy economy.  This research project aims to develop air flow models for use in wind plant design and control.  The working hypothesis is that flow modifications resulting from turbine actions, such as adjusting the angle of the turbine rotor to the incoming flow (yawing or tilting) or pulsing the surfaces that regulate power extraction, can best be understood using models of very large swirling flow structures called "macro-vortices."  Such vortices are believed to extend for many hundreds of meters downstream of turbines in a wind farm. These structures can be responsible for changing the speed, direction, and frequency of the wind exiting a turbine and impacting the performance of downstream turbines.  This research project will use computer simulations to study the generation, evolution, and decay of large-scale vortices in turbulent flows. Educational and outreach activities will leverage national and international research networks through Johns Hopkins University Society of Women Engineers. K-12 outreach will be coordinated through the Center for Educational Outreach at Johns Hopkins University and will include lectures as part of Engineering Innovation, a summer program for high school students.  The project researchers will also participate in an intersession program at a local elementary school.

This research project will develop the fundamental knowledge required to harness the potential of large-scale flow actuation, using wind turbine yaw, tilt, and cycling, in order to improve wind farm performance. Various research questions will be addressed using high-fidelity numerical datasets from a suite of Large Eddy Simulations (LES) of yawed, tilted, and periodically forced turbines. The project will characterize the properties (strength, effective core-size, positions and trajectories) of the macro-vortices generated under various conditions, including shear, surface roughness, and thermal stratification of the atmosphere, e.g. under buoyant (daytime) and stably stratified (nighttime) conditions. The project will develop reduced models that leverage lessons learned from the various LES data, as well as from basic physics of vorticity dynamics and simplified descriptions such as lifting line theory. The resulting reduced models and LES insights will be used to find improved arrangements or optimal networks of macro-vortices.  The objective would be to increase vertical entrainment of mean kinetic energy from the faster winds above the wind turbines down into the wind turbine region.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project employed advanced computer simulations to derive insights to improve wind farm operations and renewable energy yield. The project focused on building a deeper understanding of the dynamics of large-scale vortices that develop downstream of wind turbines when they are yawed during various turbine control actions. The work focused on understanding the effect of the underlying large-scale vorticity dynamics on the wind farm flow physics and power output under a range of atmospheric conditions. The research led to the development of new analytical models of the evolution of these large-scale vortices, a key factor in harnessing more wind power efficiently. Broader impacts included the education of three graduate students, as well as the development of undergraduate and graduate level courses in wind energy as well as many outreach activities. 

Intellectual Merit:

(a) Macro-Vortices: The study examined how macro-vortices form and diffuse when large wind turbines are yawed. Large Eddy Simulations (LES) helped identify how these vortices behave, contributing to better models for predicting their effects on wind farm power generation. 

(c) Analytical Model Integrating Ekman and Surface Layer Dynamics: A new model was introduced to predict wind conditions across different atmospheric stability levels, combining traditional surface layer modeling with more advanced models for higher regions of the atmosphere. 

(d) Modeling Wakes under a Range of Atmospheric Conditions: The project extended wake modeling to include a range of atmospheric conditions including wind veer—lateral wind shifts caused by Coriolis forces. 

(e) Coupled Wake Models: The Area Localized Coupled (ALC) uses localized, turbine specific descriptions to enhance engineering wind farm models and operational planning. The wind farm is partitioned into turbine areas based on the local turbine relative positions. Local atmospheric conditions based on boundary layer dynamics could thus be coupled to advanced wake models (with local parameters) in order to better predict power output in arbitrarily arranged wind farms.   

(f) Dynamic Modeling of Wind Farm Power Outputs: An innovative network-based approach was introduced to enable wind turbine and farm level power output predictions under dynamically changing wind direction and wind turbine yaw conditions. This model was used in a closed loop yaw augmented pitch control algorithm for power tracking. 

(h) Refined Theories for Wind Turbine Actuator Line Modeling: The study improved upon existing theories of aerodynamics for wind turbine force modeling, accommodating rapid variations in turbine blade width along the length of the blade. This enhancement allows for more accurate predictions of airflow and forces around turbine blades.

Broader Impacts: 

The results of the project contributed to the broader goal of enhancing renewable energy efficiency and sustainability. The project successfully integrated complex atmospheric physics with practical engineering models, leading to improved strategies and tools for wind farm design, control, and power maximization. These efforts not only advance the scientific understanding of wind energy systems but also provide tangible benefits in terms of energy efficiency and environmental impact. The project yielded 8 peer-reviewed publications, 2 doctoral theses, 2 conference papers and 56 presentations at conferences and institutional seminars.  

Broader impacts were achieved via education/training of two PhD students, 1 MS student as well as the development of a new graduate course in Wind Energy. An undergraduate independent study course was also developed by one of the graduate students, who gained both teaching and curriculum development experience.  The Co-PIs also helped to organize several educational initiatives including MiniSymposia at the 73rd and a special session at the 74th Annual Meetings of the APS Division of Fluid Dynamics, respectively on wind energy fluid mechanics and wind and solar energy. PI Meneveau’s efforts in enhancing scientific publishing through JFM Notebooks demonstrate a commitment to open and reproducible research. 

Researchers co-organized two well attended workshops on diversity and inclusion at international conferences, respectively highlighting unconscious bias and its impact on job searches. The co-PIs also took an active role in mentoring by giving lectures to high school and undergraduate students. They organized and participated in several community-building events aimed at supporting underrepresented groups in research and academia, including minority student/postdoc breakfasts and Women in Control lunches.
